alert.note: Alert for Central Chaffee County Below 9000 Ft; Eastern Sawatch Mountains above 11000 Ft; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains Between 8500 And 11000 Ft; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains above 11000 Ft; Southern Sangre De Cristo Mountains Above 11000 Ft; Southern Sangre De Cristo Mountains Between 7500 and 11000 Ft; Walsenburg Vicinity, Upper Huerfano River Basin Below 7500 Ft; Western Chaffee County Between 9000 and 11000 Ft; Western, Central Fremont County Below 8500 Ft; Wet Mountain Valley Below 8500 Ft; Wet Mountains above 10000 Ft; Wet Mountains between 6300 and 10000Ft (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued June 07 at 9:00AM MDT until June 07 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Pueblo
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WATCH FOR THE DECKER, HAYDEN PASS, JUNKINS, AND SPRING BURN SCARS IN EFFECT FROM NOON MDT TODAY THROUGH THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Flash flooding and debris flows caused by excessive rainfall are possible over the Decker, Hayden Pass, Junkins, and Spring Burn Scars. * WHERE...Portions of central Colorado and southeast Colorado, including the following areas, in central Colorado, Central and Western Chaffee County, Eastern Sawatch Mountains Above 11000 Feet, and Western and Central Fremont County Below 8500 Feet. In southeast Colorado, the Sangre de Cristo and Wet Mountains, Huerfano County, and the Wet Mountain Valley. * WHEN...From Noon MDT today through this evening. * IMPACTS...Heavy rainfall over the Decker, Hayden Pass, Junkins, and Spring Burn Scars will be possible this afternoon and evening. Slow moving thunderstorms capable of producing heavy rainfall may cause flash flooding in and near burn scars. Residents near the Decker, Hayden Pass, Junkins, and Spring Burn Scars should prepare for potential flooding impacts. Be sure to stay up to date with information from local authorities. Heavy rainfall could trigger flash flooding of low-lying areas, urbanized street flooding, and debris flows in and near recent wildfire burn scars. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - National Weather Service Meteorologists are forecasting heavy rainfall over the burn scars, which may lead to flash flooding and debris flows. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.
